results.title: You might as well live
results.creator_credit: Con Anemogiannis, Judy Menczel and Fortian Productions
results.brief_description: ‘You might as well live’ is an excellent documentary on the subject of youth suicide in Australia. The film examines why Australia has such a high youth suicide rate and what can be done about it.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Con Anemogiannis, Judy Menczel and Fortian Productions

results.title: You haven't changed a bit
results.creator_credit: Bruce Baker, Karl Holtsnider and Teleketics
results.brief_description: A dramatization about a young couple who after a quarrel take separate vacations at their respective parents’ homes. In the process they discover that despite their past associations their real identity lies in their relationship with each other.

results.title: You have to know that you like the job
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Apprentices in various areas such as bakery, mechanics, and stonemasonry talk about why they chose their particular area of work and how they feel about working in such an area.

results.title: You have struck a rock
results.brief_description: ‘You have touched a woman, you have struck a rock!’ was the cry in 1956 when 20,000 women occupied Union Buildings, the seat of the all-white South African government, to protest against the issuing of passes to black women. The film recreates this anti-apartheid womens’ campaign using a collage of rare photographs, newsreel footage and recent interviews with women involved.

results.title: You don't have to be mad
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Discusses what sort of people a psychologist can help, and how they can help them, especially in the employment field. Uses light-hearted as well as serious examples. Cast includes Bruce Spence, Graeme Blundell. Assistant producer, Rosemary Gow; director, script, Greg Reading; photographers, John Hosking, Ross King; editor, Tom Foley; sound, Lloyd Carrick, Rod Simmons; commentator, Paul Ricketts.

results.title: You can go a long way!
results.creator_credit: Donald Wilder and San Life Assurance Co of Canada
results.brief_description: Designed to allow students to explore, in their own way, the reasons why it is wise to finish school, and get as much training and education as possible before looking for a job. Tells in a light way what parents and teachers sometimes knock themselves out trying to prove: that competition is keen in the bread-and -butter world and that the best jobs go to the candidate with the best qualifications.

results.title: You can do it!
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Michael E. Bernard. This video is designed to aid students (and others) in developing the skills and essential attitudes necessary for success in school and happiness in life. The video addresses issues such as goal setting, time management, attitudes, self-confidence, self-motivation, exam anxiety and relationships.

results.title: You can do anything
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The Kirinara Hostel in N.S.W. offers an educational program specifically designed for young Aboriginal and Islander people. The video focuses on students at the hostel and includes interviews with ex-students who have pursued careers in a diverse range of fields including law, teaching, football and dance. The graduates stress the importance of individuals setting realistic goals for themselves as well as the need for Aboriginal education support schemes to assist young Aboriginal people to achieve their full educational potential.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Aviva Ziegler, Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training and Film Australia

results.title: You can't always tell
results.creator_credit: Scott Hicks, Terry Jennings and Chrysalis Films
results.brief_description: This film aims to inform children in the seven to twelve age group of the problem of child molesting. It contains a series of dramatised scenes showing situations in which children can find themselves. Shows children how to avoid putting themselves at risk with strangers.
